image.altText: Marles stands in front of a military aircraft speaking to media.

items.synopsis: The defence minister says he wants to clear the air over $3 million worth of taxpayer funded flights charged by his office since April last year, but can't for security reasons.

title.children: Defence Minister Richard Marles defends $3 million spend on taxpayer-funded RAAF flights

image.altText: Jetstar and Qantas planes next to each other on the tarmac at an airport.

items.synopsis: Qantas boss Alan Joyce has confirmed the airline and its subsidiary Jetstar have about $570 million in unclaimed credits. Here's how to figure out if you're owed a refund or how to redeem your credits.

title.children: Qantas and Jetstar are holding more than half a billion dollars in flight credits. Here's how to figure out what you're owed

image.altText: For Sale signage outside a suburban house.

items.synopsis: After a brief downturn earlier in the year, Australia's housing market is firmly in recovery mode, with CoreLogic data showing house prices increased for a sixth consecutive month in August.

title.children: House prices rise for sixth straight month, with interest rate outlook likely to see 'active' selling season

image.altText: A woman in pink shirt standing in city street.

items.synopsis: Young culturally diverse Australians continue to face discrimination when trying to find work, according to recent studies. Experts found non-Anglo Australians struggle to get a job interview, despite being well qualified, and some are altering their identities on paper to get a fair go.

title.children: If you're a graduate with an English-sounding name, you may be closer to securing a job than some of your peers

image.altText: A baby and a young woman in a car. Both have their faces blurred.

items.synopsis: As Crystal waited, along with thousands of others, for public housing in Western Australia, her 10-month-old son Kenneth died. Advocates say her story is becoming increasingly common.

title.children: Crystal has finally been offered a place to live, but it came too late for her baby son

image.altText: Composite picture of Reserve Bank deputy governor Guy Debelle (left) and Andrew Forrest (right).

items.synopsis: Australia's share market opens down as Fortescue sees another high profile resignation. Follow the day's business news with our live blog.

title.children: Guy Debelle quits Andrew Forrest's Fortescue Future Industries, ASX down in early trade

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Guy Debelle, the former Reserve Bank deputy governor, has quit Andrew Forrest's Fortescue Future Industries (FFI). The ABC understands it happened weeks ago, well before the recent collection of resignations that have hit the troubled company. But he has now joined Tivan Limited (ASX: TVN), a small cap critical minerals company. Tivan informed the Australian Securities Exchange of Debelle's move this morning, saying he's agreed to join the board of Tivan in the role of non-executive director, effective as of 1 September 2023. "After leaving the RBA, Dr Debelle worked at Fortescue Future Industries as CFO and non-executive director," the statement says. "Other precious positions he has held include: the International Monetary Fund, Bank for International Settlements, Australian Treasury, visiting Professor of Economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, chair of the Global Foreign Exchange Committee, chair of the Council of Financial Regulators working group on Climate Finance, chair of the BIS Markets Committee." Tivan says Debelle has confirmed his intention to invest $25,000 in the company by way of a private placement of shares at a price of 7.2 cents, consistent with the investment made by his fellow directors in the placement announced on 12 July 2023. It says this is subject to the approval of shareholders at the Company's 2023 annual general meeting. Dr Debelle said in a statement: "I am excited to join Tivan who are focused on realising the great opportunity Australia has in the green transition, particularly in the critical minerals space. I am looking forward to working with the team to further enhance Tivan's inclusive and sustainable approach to developing its resources to benefit the community and deliver value for its shareholders."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Guy Debelle quits Andrew Forrest's Fortescue Future Industries

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Mark Butler, the federal Minister for Health, was on ABC News Breakfast this morning. He reminded viewers that millions of Australians will be able to get 60 days' worth of medicine on a single script from today. Some pharmacists opposed this measure and waged an aggressive campaign in the media to stop it happening, but they weren't able to. From today, nearly 100 common medicines listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS ) will have the option of a 60-day prescription. This means many patients can now receive twice the medication for the cost of a single prescription. But that's just the start. The changes are happening in 3 stages over 12 months and will apply to more than 300 medicines once completed on 1 September 2024. You can learn more about the changes here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 60 days of medicine from a single script starts today

image.altText: Crowds of people queue at a supermarket.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Hong Kong closes schools, cancels flights as typhoon approaches, Walking Dead spin-offs to resume production amid Hollywood strike. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In the US state of Missouri, a judge has ruled that the 84-year-old white homeowner who shot a black teenager after he mistakenly went to the man’s house in April must stand trial. Clay County Judge Louis Angles issued the ruling after a dozen witnesses spoke at a preliminary hearing, The witnesses included Ralph Yarl, the teenager who was shot by Andrew Lester on April 13 when Yarl went to the wrong house to pick up his younger brothers. Lester, a retired aircraft mechanic, is charged with first-degree assault and armed criminal action. He previously pleaded not guilty in the shooting that shocked the country and renewed national debates about gun policies
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US judge rules white man will stand trial for shooting black teen who went to wrong house

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Two spinoffs of The Walking Dead and the next season of Interview With the Vampire have been given the green light to resume production. The three AMC series are the highest-profile television productions yet to get interim agreement from the S creen Actors Guild-American Federation of Television and Radio Artists amid its strike in Hollywood. The approval was granted because the channel AMC and production company Stalwart Films are not part of the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers (AMPTP) — the coalition of studios the actors are striking against. Instead, they are "authorised companies" that abide by the contracts reached by the AMPTP. No new writing will be allowed on the series because the Writers Guild of America has opted not to grant any such agreements.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: TV shows to resume production amid Hollywood strike

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hong Kong is bracing for the arrival of Super Typhoon Saola. It is packing winds of more than 200kph and is expected to move towards the coast of eastern Guangdong, the neighbouring province on the Chinese mainland. It could be among the five strongest typhoons to hit Guangdong since 1949, according to Chinese authorities. Saola is expected to skirt within 100km of Hong Kong on Friday night and Saturday morning, causing weather conditions to deteriorate rapidly, the city's weather observatory says. All schools in Hong Kong will be closed on Friday, despite being the first day of term for many, the government said. Hong Kong's Observatory says it expects heavy rain and violent winds while the city's water level is expected to "rise appreciably" until Saturday, with the potential for serious flooding. The city's flagship carrier Cathay Pacific says all flights in and out of Hong Kong between 2pm local time on Friday and 10am on Saturday have been cancelled.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hong Kong closes schools, cancels flights in preparation for typhoon
